channel.title: Latest alerts from washingtonpost.com
channel.description: An unofficial feed created by Derek Willis.

item.title: Israel’s Supreme Court rules that ultra-Orthodox must do military service, throwing Netanyahu’s government into turmoil
item.description: The ruling on the controversial issue of the haredim engaging in compulsory military service could lead to the ultra-Orthodox parties quitting the ruling coalition and bringing down Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s government.

item.title: Florida Panthers win the Stanley Cup for the first time, taking Game 7 of the finals to top Connor McDavid's Edmonton Oilers
item.description: The Panthers jumped out to a 3-0 series lead in the finals but were then sent reeling by the resilient Oilers. They dropped Games 4, 5 and 6 to set up the Game 7 clash in South Florida on Monday night. The Oilers' loss leaves McDavid, Edmonton's dazzling captain, still searching for the Stanley Cup. A Canadian team has not won the Stanley Cup since the Montreal Canadiens in 1993.

item.title: Two federal court rulings threaten the future of Biden administration’s new student loan repayment plan
item.description: Judges in Kansas and Missouri issued separate injunctions Monday preventing the government from fully implementing and forgiving any more loans through the Save program while they consider lawsuits to end the administration’s plan.

item.title: WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange expected to plead guilty to a felony, according to court filing
item.description: A court filing indicates the controversial former hacker plans to plead guilty to a single felony count of violating the Espionage Act for his role in obtaining and publishing classified military and diplomatic documents in 2010. The plea deal would end a long-running legal saga and a transatlantic tug-of-war that pitted national security against press freedom.

item.title: The way your name is spelled is a clue about when you were born. Look up your name to see how trendy it is (or was).
item.description: The Washington Post’s Department of Data dove deep into the trendiest baby names and found one surprising thing almost all of them have in common. We even created a tool to show how any American name fits the trend.

item.title: They don’t like Biden. They don’t like Trump either. Meet the ‘double haters’ who could decide the election.
item.description: Many voters express resignation, dismay and anger over being asked to choose between Joe Biden and Donald Trump again. These double haters — voters who are dissatisfied with both major-party choices — are likely to prove a critical voting bloc in November.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Best friend is poised to estrange parents over misunderstanding
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Best friend is poised to estrange parents over misunderstanding

item.title: Extreme wildfires around the world have doubled in the past 20 years, new study finds
item.description: The analysis, published Monday in the journal Nature Ecology & Evolution, found that climate change is exacerbating fire weather and extreme blazes, which emit high levels of carbon and are often deadly. The six most extreme fire years have occurred since 2017, researchers said.

item.title: Vladimir Kara-Murza from a prison colony in Russia: Putin’s definition of a ‘foreign agent’? Anyone who opposes him.
item.description: I am not a foreign agent, the Russian dissident writes.

item.title: Supreme Court to review Tenn. law banning gender transition care for minors in justices’ first opportunity to weigh in on treatments
item.description: Transgender young people, their families and medical providers in Tennessee asked the Supreme Court to review an appeals court decision that upheld the laws banning gender transition care for people younger than 18. Twenty-three states have passed such bans since 2021.

item.title: An ancient beach reopens in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Monday points.

item.title: Russia attacks. Trump rhetoric. Israeli airstrikes. Global heat. Gen Z struggles. Mail surveillance. Track trials. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Could a month at an all-inclusive resort in Mexico cost the same as rent in a big U.S. city? This man tried it to find out.
item.description: Expedia contacted TikToker Ben Keenan with an offer to cover the cost of accommodations at a luxury resort on the Yucatán Peninsula. He had nothing to lose, so he flew to Mexico to put his viral question to the test.

item.title: Do you think like a key swing-state voter? Answer these 8 questions to find out.
item.description: See what you have in common with this small but influential subset of voters who might decide the election.

item.title: Big Tobacco courts Black and LGBTQ+ activists to help loosen vaping regulations and fight menthol cigarette ban
item.description:
The tobacco industry has expanded alliances with activists representing Black, LGBTQ+ and other disenfranchised groups to defend products that public health experts say are harmful.
Anti-tobacco activists say these partnerships help companies gain credibility among regulators and lawmakers, as vaping groups lobby the Food and Drug Administration to approve more e-cigarette products and tobacco firms fight a Biden administration plan to ban menthol cigarettes.

item.title: Still need to finish this weekend’s On the Record? We’ve got you.
item.description: Play now to finish out your score for the week.

item.title: ‘You need to know this story’: In 1964, the Klan killed three activists and shocked the nation
item.description: Amid Freedom Summer, a daring effort to register Black Mississippians to vote, three young civil rights workers came to the state’s small town of Philadelphia to check on a church burning. Before the sun rose the next morning, they would all be dead. The town is still grappling with that violent chapter of history on the murders’ 60th anniversary.

item.title: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now
item.description: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now

item.title: Tech firms chase fusion energy and other miracles as AI drains the power grid
item.description: Big Tech companies are going all in on experimental clean-energy projects that have long odds of success anytime soon, even as their race to dominate artificial intelligence boosts demand for fossil fuels.

item.title: D.C. just reached 100 degrees for the first time in almost eight years
item.description: Today is the first time since Aug. 15, 2016, that Washington's temperature has hit the century mark. It ends the fifth-longest streak on record without hitting 100 degrees and comes as a heat wave now baking the East Coast expands into the Mid-Atlantic.

item.title: Arizona delegates gathered this month to discuss a secret plan: A far-right effort to throw Trump’s nomination into chaos
item.description: The exact motive behind the plotting remained unclear, but it set off a scramble within the Trump campaign to replace the delegates. One campaign staffer involved in the cleanup described the scheme as an “existential threat” to Trump’s nomination next month.

item.title: Ask Sahaj: My family says I’m ‘selfish’ for not wanting my mom to live with me
item.description: Ask Sahaj: My family says I’m ‘selfish’ for not wanting my mom to live with me

item.title: For Black families, the race to preserve civil rights history in the South comes with an unexpected sacrifice
item.description: With the 60th anniversary of the march from Selma to Montgomery approaching next year, Phillip Howard is working to save sites where Martin Luther King Jr. and his followers camped out. But the Black families who still own the land face difficult questions about what they owe to preserving public memory — particularly as civil rights education comes under threat.

item.title: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.
item.description: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.

item.title: Billions of people this week felt the deadly intensity of heat waves fueled by climate change
item.description: A week of scorching heat across five continents shows how human-driven warming has raised the baseline of normal temperatures, scientists say, fueling more frequent extremes. In just the past seven days, a majority of the planet experienced heat waves that were made more likely by climate change, and more than 1,000 temperature records fell around the globe.

item.title: She spent 23 years asking who killed her mom. Then her phone rang.
item.description: Lauren Preer spent more than two decades waiting for answers in the brutal killing of her mother, Leslie J. Preer, in her Chevy Chase, Md., home. She hoped an arrest would bring closure. Instead, she felt shock — then betrayal and rage.

item.title: U.S. restrictions on how far Ukraine can fire American weapons into Russia leave key bases out of range, Ukrainian officials say
item.description: The two officials say that the Biden administration’s lifting of a ban on targets in Russia has helped their military reduce some incoming attacks, but that air bases used by planes that drop highly destructive glide bombs are beyond a range set by Washington.

item.title: Nevada judge dismisses case against Trump electors, ruling prosecutors chose the wrong jurisdiction to file the case
item.description: The decision marks a setback for efforts to prosecute those who submitted certificates falsely declaring Donald Trump the winner of the 2020 election. The Nevada attorney general’s office said it would appeal.

item.title: It could feel like 105 degrees in D.C. on Saturday. Officials have issued a heat advisory for the region.
item.description: Temperatures could be the highest in the region since August 2016. Sunday’s heat is expected to be similarly intense.

item.title: Carolyn Hax chat: Dad thinks cancer survivor dyed hair purple for attention
item.description: Carolyn Hax chat: Dad thinks cancer survivor dyed hair purple for attention

item.title: Supreme Court upholds gun ban for people subject to domestic-violence restraining orders in rare victory for firearms restrictions
item.description: A federal law that strips guns from those deemed dangerous was among a number of firearms restrictions imperiled after the Supreme Court’s conservative majority bolstered gun rights in its 2022 decision, known as New York State Rifle & Pistol Association v. Bruen.

item.title: 10 questions, plus a bonus wager! It’s the weekend edition of On the Record.
item.description: 10 questions, plus a bonus wager! It’s the weekend edition of On the Record.

item.title: Robert Winnett will not join The Post as editor
item.description: Winnett, deputy editor of London’s Telegraph Media Group, who was to lead The Washington Post newsroom, faced questions about his work in England, including stories based on illicitly obtained records. Early Friday, the editor of the Telegraph, Chris Evans, told staff Winnett will stay with the paper.

item.title: Trump donation surge. Heat wave. Donald Sutherland. Murder suspect. AI emissions. Chimp medicine. Ancient beach. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Donald Trump’s felony conviction fuels a donation surge that narrows Biden’s advantage
item.description: The Trump campaign and an allied super PAC received a huge influx of cash in the days following his May conviction on 34 felony counts of falsifying business records. The surge in post-conviction donations — captured in part in May reports filed to the Federal Election Commission on Thursday — is giving Trump a significant boost as he tries to narrow the Biden campaign’s once-enormous cash advantage.

item.title: Bayer is pushing Congress for legislation — and helped shape a provision — that could help fight lawsuits tying Roundup to cancer
item.description: The company has paid billions of dollars in settlements, even as it maintains its weedkiller is safe and denies wrongdoing. A Bayer-backed provision in the House’s sweeping agricultural bill could halt some lawsuits, according to documents viewed by The Washington Post and seven people familiar with the matter.

item.title: Ex-Prince George’s County councilman Mel Franklin charged with embezzling campaign funds for personal expenses
item.description: At least $130,000 of his campaign funds were used to pay for personal expenses, including his rent, loans and cosmetic procedures for him and a close friend, prosecutors allege. Franklin abruptly resigned Friday from his seat after serving on the council for nearly 14 years.

item.title: Los Angeles Lakers to hire JJ Redick as head coach. The former NBA player co-hosts a podcast with Lakers star LeBron James.
item.description: Redick, 39, had a 15-year NBA playing career but has no previous coaching experience. He replaces Darvin Ham, who was fired last month. Redick hosts multiple popular basketball-related podcasts, including one he launched with James in March.

item.title: Donald Sutherland dies at 88. The actor had a stunning range in films such as ‘Ordinary People’ and ‘The Hunger Games.’
item.description: Tall, expressive and possessing remarkable versatility, his roles ranged from an irreverent G.I. in “The Dirty Dozen” to the antiwar comedy “M.A.S.H.” and the campus romp “Animal House” in the 1970s to the dystopian leader in the recent “Hunger Games” franchise.

item.title: Ask Tara: My ex-husband lives two doors from me. How do I stop feeling he is too close?
item.description: Well+Being editor Tara Parker-Pope answers your questions with science-based advice.

item.title: TikTok files brief to challenge potential ban, kicking off a consequential legal battle between the popular app and U.S. government
item.description: The brief, filed by TikTok and a group of eight creators, argues that a law demanding TikTok’s China-based owner, ByteDance, sell its U.S. operations by Jan. 19 or face a nationwide ban would violate Americans’ First Amendment right to free expression. TikTok also went on the offensive, sharing for the first time internal documents from years of failed negotiations with the federal government that it says show the Biden administration was not operating in good faith.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: How to fix low self-esteem so it doesn’t drag down a marriage?
item.description: Carolyn Hax: How to fix low self-esteem so it doesn’t drag down a marriage?

item.title: Supreme Court upholds Trump’s tax on off-shore earnings, rejecting lawsuit that could have disrupted U.S. tax system
item.description: The case asked whether an obscure provision of then-President Donald Trump’s 2017 tax package is permitted under Congress’s limited powers of taxation. Some saw the lawsuit as an effort to preemptively block Congress from creating a wealth tax.

item.title: A notable memoir in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Thursday points.

item.title: Dutch leader Mark Rutte is poised to become new NATO secretary general, replacing Jens Stoltenberg, after competition drops out
item.description: The change in leadership, which could be announced within days, comes amid worry over the return of former U.S. president Donald Trump. The prime minister of the Netherlands is known for his pragmatic outlook and willingness to work with Trump should he win the 2024 election.

item.title: Despite a Biden-Xi agreement to crack down on fentanyl, Chinese sellers are open for business
item.description: A booming online marketplace for shipping small but potent packages of the chemicals used in the production of fentanyl from China to Mexico remains largely unhindered, a Post investigation found.

item.title: Heat wave. Ten Commandments. Hajj deaths. Stonehenge. Alzheimer’s hope. Wet bag. Summer solstice. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: The 2024 ‘Deciders’: Who are they and what makes them tick?
item.description: In a nation where many voters have made up their minds in the upcoming presidential election, 6 in 10 voters in key battleground states turn out sporadically or are not firmly committed to President Biden or Donald Trump. These Deciders skew young and non-White and are even more sour on major candidates than the broader electorate. The Washington Post and the Schar School of Policy and Government at George Mason University surveyed 3,513 registered voters in six key states to find out what they think.

item.title: A rare gene mutation helps people resist Alzheimer’s disease, study finds — a hopeful clue for new therapies
item.description: In a study published Wednesday in the New England Journal of Medicine, researchers reported 27 members of an extended Colombian family carry extreme genetic risk for Alzheimer’s, along with a copy of a protective gene called Christchurch. Cognitive decline in this singular group was delayed by about five years, suggesting that a drug that emulates the gene could have similar effects.

item.title: Iran signals a major boost to nuclear program at key site
item.description: The expansion in Iran’s most heavily protected nuclear facility could triple the site’s production of enriched uranium and give Tehran new options for quickly assembling a nuclear arsenal if it chooses to, according to confidential documents and analysis by weapons experts.
